div.p: The first step to access our new cloud-based trading environment is to create a user account. Simply access our home page, click the register button and enter your name, email address, and create a password. You will receive a notice in your email that your account is now active.

The next step involves linking your account to the Clearing Firm. Login to your account and select the Settings gear icon. Select Invitations to view and accept any pending invites from your Clearing Firm. Once accepted, your account is fully activated and you can immediately begin to trade.
Note: Issues with accessing market data may indicate that the firm needs to complete your risk setup. Please contact your Clearing Firm if you experience issues on your first login attempt.
The software includes a Take a Tour workspace. Once opened, the tour will give you an introduction to the various widgets and available functionality.

A workspace is trading environment tailored to your preferences. It contains a collection of widgets you use to monitor prices, place orders, track fills, and more. You can use create a single workspace for all of your trading, or you can create multiple workspaces with widgets suited to specific trading needs. For example, you can:

ul.li: Create separate workspaces for different markets, brokers, or customers
Create a workspace that has a preformatted Fill window that shows specific information

div.p: For example, here is a workspace focused on monitoring and trading the 10-year and 30-year treasury notes.
At the top of your workspace is the title bar.
Beneath the title bar is the workspace canvas, where you can add various widgets.
NexTrader supplies several widgets that focus on specific trading needs. You can add as many widgets as you need to meet your trading needs.

tr.td: Monitor market activity and submit orders for an individual instrument
Monitor market activity and submit orders for multiple instruments

tr.td: See a historical record of all account activity
View all transactions regarding an instrument
Display historical market data in a variety of charts
View all of the events and system messages

div.p: Creating a workspace is easy. Simply click Create a workspace and give it a name.
And your new workspace opens.
div.h3: Changing the look of your workspace
div.p: If you don’t like the workspace background, you can change it.

li.p: From the Settings menu, select Change background.
(You might be wondering about that Change theme item. We’ll look at that one when we talk about launching widgets.)
Browse through the different backgrounds until you find one you like.
As you select different choices, the background dynamically updates.
When you find the one you like, click Close.

div.div:
Adding Widgets to Your Workspace
Adding Widgets to Your Workspace
Now that you have a workspace, you can starting adding the widgets you want to use. You can add widgets in two ways:
Searching for an instrument or product widget
You can use Nextrader’s robust search functionality to find an instrument or product and launch a widget for it.
In the search field, start typing the name of a product or instrument. You can type a symbol, like ZB, or a description, like treasury.
As you type each character, Nextrader automatically starts displaying items that contain your characters.
When you see the product or instrument you want to use, hover over it to see which widgets you can use for that item. For example, if you select an instrument, you will see more widgets than if you select a product.
Select the widget you want to add. In this case, you select Open MD Trader, so Nextrader adds the widget to your workspace.
Notice the icon for your widget appears in the workspace title bar. In fact, every time you add a widget, its icon is added to the title bar.
If you want to move it somewhere else, all you have to do is drag the widget’s title bar to where you want it.
Adding a widget from the widget menu
Alternatively, you can add a widget to your workspace by selecting a widget from the widget menu.
Click the + in the title bar to display the widget menu.
Select the widget you want to add.
In this case, you add an MD Trader widget.
As you can see, the MD Trader widget doesn’t have an instrument yet. So you need to add the instrument to the widget.
Search for the instrument you want to add to the widget.
Continue adding widgets to complete your workspace, such as an Order Book widget. The Order Book widget is not tied to an instrument or product, so you don’t have to do anything else to use it.
Arrange the widgets so the workspace looks like you want.
When you are done adding and arranging widgets, save the workspace by clicking
in the title bar.

Using the MD Trader
Using the MD Trader
Overview
The MD Trader Widget allows you to quickly submit orders using a familiar market-depth ladder. The MD Trader Widget also gives you a complete overview of a particular contact including the following:
Net Change: the distance of the current price (i.e., inside market) to the contract’s opening price.
High: the contract’s highest trading price for the current session.
Low: the contract’s lowest trading price for the current session.
Open: the contract’s opening price.
Volume: the total number of lots traded.
As with most widgets, you can access the MD Trader window using one of the following methods:
Search for a contract in the Title Bar: type the contract’s name in the search box and select Open in MD Trader to begin trading.
Use the plus icon: click the plus (+) icon and select MD Trader. Right-click a contract’s name in the Market Grid: select Open Widget then MD Trader.
Adding a Contract
You can add a contract to any opened MD Trader widget by using the new tab button at the bottom of the ladder. This opens the Add an Instrument window and allows you to either search for a contract or use the instrument explorer.
You can find out more about tabs below.
Submitting Orders
The MD Trader widget allows you to set all parameters relating to an order prior to submitting into the market.
Fill/Position Indicator
Each time you receive a fill, that tab in the MD Trader widget displays your updated position in the contract.
Tips and Tricks: Centering the Market
You can recenter the MD Trader ladder to focus on the inside market by selecting the MD Trader widget and pressing the Space Bar.
In addition, you can recenter all MD Trader ladders in a workspace by right-clicking the price ladder in any MD Trader widget.
Tips and Tricks: Multiple Orders at the Same Price
Users often submit multiple orders at the same price level. When this occurs, the software shows the total number of your orders at that price level.
You can access and change each separate order by pressing the arrow (>) button. This opens a side-drawer which shows the different orders. You can then select an individual order or ctrl-click and select multiple orders.
Once selected, you can perform a cancel/replace by moving any order to a different price level.
Reorder Columns
Click on any column heading in MD Trader to move that column to a different place. For example, you can place the Last-Traded-Quantity (LTQ) and Working Orders (Work) columns side-by-side.

div.p: The Market Grid allows you to monitor the current market for multiple instruments. You can also quickly submit orders by opening the Order Ticket widget directly from the Market Grid.
Add contracts and products using one of the following methods:

ul.li: Single contract: simply click a row in the Market Grid to access the Instrument Explorer. The selected contract appears in that row.
Multiple contracts for a product: use the plus (+) button to add a tab and select From Product to open a tab containing all available contracts for that product.

div.p: Clicking a row in the Market Grid allows you to open that product in a different widget (including MD Trader, Chart, Order Ticket, and Time and Sales).
For rapid order entry, you may click on the BidQty, BidPrc, AskQty, or AskPrc column to open an Order Ticket with the selected value populated. For more information
div.h3: Submitting Orders via the Order Ticket
div.p: The order ticket is currently only accessible via the Market Grid.
From the market grid, you can open an order ticket with a:
Left-click on:

ul.li: BidQty, BidPrice: open a buy ticket to join the inside bid, and zero as the qty
AskQty, AskPrice: open a sell ticket to join the inside offer, and zero as the qty

div.p: Right-click on:

ul.li: BidQty: open a sell ticket to hit the inside bid and BidQty as the qty
BidPrice: open a sell ticket to hit the inside bid and zero as the qty
AskQty: open a buy ticket to lift the inside offer and AskQty as the qty
AskPrice: open a buy ticket to lift the inside offer and zero as the qty
Contract -> open order ticket-> get a two-sided ticket where the Last Traded Price is pre-populated and zero as the qty

div.p: The order ticket shows the inside market.
You can click on the inside market to adjust the price and quantity fields -- this follows the same rules as the market grid.
Order Tickets can be "docked" (Control is in the order tickets’ settings menu).
You can use the Order Book widget to manage your working orders. The widget lists all of your working orders and updates them as trading activity occurs.
With the Order Book widget, you can:

ul.li: Change the quantity or price of a working order
Delete single or multiple working orders
Display a history of an order’s activity

div.p: You can use this widget to see a list of your orders currently working in the market. For each order, you can determine things like the working quantity, order type, percent filled, and so on.

You can also sort or filter the list based on values for a column. If you hover the mouse cursor over the right side of a column title, the cursor changes to a hand to let you know you can use it to change the display. For example, you can sort or filter the display by contracts by hovering over the Contract column and clicking the mouse.
You can change the quantity or price of a working order by selecting the order you want to change. You can change the values and click Change.
To delete working orders, select the order or orders you want to delete and click Delete.
You can also delete all of your working orders by clicking Delete All. As a precaution, you are asked to confirm deleting all working orders.
If you do not want to confirm these deletes, you can disable the confirmation by checking the Do not show this confirmation again option, or you can change the setting in the widget configuration.
div.h3: Displaying historical activity for an order
div.p: You can also display all of the changes made to an order due to trades or manual order changes. To display the historical activity, select one or more orders and click History. In this case, you can see that the order quantity was reduced from 15 to 12.
Launching the Fills widget provides you with detailed exchange-confirmed fills. The widget includes all fills you received since you created your account.
You can also export fills to a .csv file. Select the fill rows you want to export and right-click in the selection to display the Export Rows context menu.
You can launch the Positions widget to track your position (SODs and any daily transactions) and P&L across your accounts.
You can configure the widget to customize how you want to group and order the positions. To change the order of a grouping, drag the group up or down as desired.

You can easily open the MD Trader widget from the Position widget. Right-click on any contract, product, or account and open the widget. If you open an MD Trader widget for an item with multiple children, an MD Trader widgets opens for each contract. For example, if you opened MD Trader from the 6E product in the following Positions widget, two MD Trader widgets would open for the 6E Mar14 and 6E Jun14 contracts.

div.div: Monitoring All Trading Activity for a Contract
div.h2: Monitoring All Trading Activity for a Contract
div.p: If you want to see all trades that occurred for a single contract during the current trading session, you can launch the Time and Sales widget for the contract.

By default, the widget displays all transactions for an instrument and highlights transactions with quantities greater than 50. You can configure the widget to add or remove instruments and to specify whether to include or highlight a transaction based on its quantity.
You can launch the Audit Trail widget to display order and fill information, exchange announcements, and error messages that occurred since your account was created:

li.p: Order related messages include messages to and from the exchange including fills, add/change/delete orders and inquiries.
Exchange announcements include busted trades and pre/post opening/closing product activity.
Error messages provide notification of an invalid action.

div.p: You can hover over a column name to access filters for the column values.
You can also jump to any date and time in the history of the account.

Order types allow you to specify how an order behaves when it enters the market. For example, you may want an order to immediately fill at the current best price (market order) or to only fill at a particular price (limit order).

Order Types differ from order restrictions which set how the order behaves during the session. For example, an order may delete if not filled by the end of the session (Day) or may persist until filled or canceled (GTC).
A Market order is an order placed without a price with the intention of hitting the best Bid or taking the best Offer currently available in the market. The order fills at the current best price.
Market orders may partially fill at multiple price levels.

For example, if you submit a 100-lot bid at $15.25 but there are only 10 ask orders at the price, you will receive a partial fill at $15.25. The remaining quantity of your working order (90-lots) will attempt to fill at each of the next best prices (e.g., 15.50, 15.75, etc) until the total order fills.
To place a market order, simply select Market in the order types drop-down, set the quantity in the MD Trader widget and select the direction you wish to trade.

Limit orders allow you to submit an order at a specific limit price. Like market orders, limit orders allow for partial fills however, the remaining quantity continues to work in the market at the original limit price.
To place a limit order, simply select Limit in the order types drop-down, set the quantity in the MD Trader widget and select the price level and direction you wish to trade.
Note: Limits differ from Stop Limit which allow you to select a range of prices (e.g., number of ticks aways from) near the limit price.

Stop Market orders allow you to select a trigger price which determines when the software submits a market order. When the market passes the trigger price, a market order enters the market and fills at the best market price.
The order may fill at a worst level than the trigger price and also may partially fill at multiple price levels.

Stop Limit orders allow you to select a trigger price which determines when the software submits a limit order. When the market passes the trigger price, a limit order enters the market and fills at the trigger price.
If partially filled, the remaining volume continues to work in the market at the trigger price level.
Order restrictions set conditions that determine when an order expiries. These are commonly referred as Time-in-Force restrictions.
For example, an order may delete if not filled by the end of the session (Day) or may persist until filled or canceled (GTC).
Good-til-Cancel (GTC) orders are entered at a specific price and may remain working at the exchange through multiple sessions until either filled or manually canceled by the trader.
GTC orders allow traders to maintain their position-in-queue across multiple trading sessions/dates.

Day orders, also known as Good-til-Day (GTD) orders, are entered at a specific price and may remain working at the exchange through the end of the current trading day until either filled or manually canceled by the trader.
Day orders allow traders to maintain their position-in-queue until the end of the trading day.
